Post:f2fa09b00f76.title: Why I Put Away My Confederate Flags

User:a0b1870362ed.name: Jarrod Davis
User:a0b1870362ed.bio: Husband, father, writer, jogger, eater. Navigating a world Im not adequately prepared for. Check out my passion project: www.creatorcreaturecollards.com

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_0.name: e7f3
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_0.text: Why I Put Away My Confederate Flags

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_1.name: e194
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_1.text: Photo by Bernard Hermant on Unsplash

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_2.text: I am and have always been fiercely proud to be Southern. I speak Southern, and I eat Southern. I feel sad for those poor souls who are not blessed to be Southern, and at the same time I dont want them to know how great the South is because I dont want them moving here.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_3.name: 02b4
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_3.text: Others are free to disagree with me. We all have the right to be wrong.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_4.name: d1e1
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_4.text: I grew up around, and myself proudly displayed, Confederate flags.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_5.text: In High School, I wore a jacket with a Confederate flag patch on the sleeve. My truck had both a Confederate flag license plate and a sticker on the window. Even my High School ring had a Confederate flag on it.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_6.name: 130b
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_6.text: This probably sounds bizarre to many of you, but it was not to us. The Confederate flag was a common symbol of Southern pride and heritage, in spite of its association with and usage by white supremacist organizations.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_7.name: a4e5
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_7.text: If objections were ever raised, our default response was always, Its heritage, not hatred. We dont celebrate the enslavement and abuse of millions of Africans, we dont participate in the ongoing mistreatment of their descendants, but we do love being Southern, and this flag is a symbol of that, no matter what others might say.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_8.text: In the Fall of 2002, when I was nineteen years old, I had a single, short conversation that made me reevaluate that symbol.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_9.text: I was working year round at a Christian camp. One of the volunteers there was a man named Hank, whom I had known for a few years. One Saturday, after our day of basketball ministry had ended, Hank sat beside me on the bleachers.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_10.name: 51c8
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_10.text: Hey, Jarrod, he said, I wanted to talk to you about something. Ive noticed the Confederate flag on your truck.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_11.name: 3fe9
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_11.text: I mentally rolled my eyes before letting forth with my prepared response: Its heritage, not hatred. Im from the South and Im proud of that. Im not racist.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_12.name: 0ae1
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_12.text: I understand that, Hank said. I know you, and I dont think youre racist. And I know that you love Jesus, and that you want to tell other people about Jesus. I know that you love people. But when people see that flag, they dont think of that, they think of hatred. They assume you hate them because they see you with that flag. I would hate for someone to get the wrong idea about you, or about Jesus, because of that flag.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_13.name: fd6e
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_13.text: That was it. The conversation moved on to other topics from there, and Hank never said anything about it to me again.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_14.name: 8b49
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_14.text: But a few days later, I removed the Confederate flags from my truck. I havent displayed a Confederate flag since.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_15.text: That conversation had an effect on me that no prior conversation had, and the reason why is friendship.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_16.name: 6d56
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_16.text: Hank and I were friends for a few years before that conversation. He respected me, and I respected him. We worked together, played together, and annoyed each other. When he broached a sensitive subject, it was as a friend, not a stranger or an enemy.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_17.name: b0f7
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_17.text: Hank acknowledged both my perspective and my deeper purpose. He never told me I was wrong, but accepted my explanation as right from my point of view. However, because he and I were friends, he was able to know what meant the most to me, where my heart was. He did not accuse me of anything, but appealed to something better in me.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_18.name: 7f05
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_18.text: Hank gave me no ultimatum. He presented an idea, and let me make my own conclusion. If I had chosen differently, Hank would have remained my friend. But he left the decision up to me.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_19.name: a009
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_19.text: You cannot change someones mind through accusations, demands and ultimatums. That causes them to dig in their heels, throw up their defenses, and double-down on whatever it is you want them to change.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_20.name: 77dc
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_20.text: Racism is an ongoing American sin.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_21.name: 7c6a
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_21.text: It is multifaceted and complex, nowhere near as simple and straightforward as many of us wish it to be.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_22.name: 467f
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_22.text: Racism is both prevalent and subtle. It is deeply ingrained in our society and culture, so much so that we think of it as normal. When light is shined on our systemized racism, we protect it as the status quo.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_23.text: Thats why I didnt want to take down my Confederate flags. I saw them as one thing, even if the world saw them as something else. Its not my fault that others use this symbol differently than what I intend.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_24.name: dc2a
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_24.text: But I cant be willfully nave and ignore the message that most of the world receives. No matter what intention I might have in flying that flag, the world will continue to see it as a symbol of hatred and violence. This is not news.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_25.name: c038
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_25.text: It has been nearly twenty years since that conversation with Hank. In that time, I have had to learn how to listen. I have had to sit through uncomfortable lessons. I have had to acknowledge my own complicity in racism, and I have dug in my heels and refused to acknowledge my failures far too often.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_26.name: 773c
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_26.text: I am still learning. I am still growing. To my shame, I am only now starting to speak out against something Ive claimed Im against my whole life.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_27.name: 28bc
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_27.text: It has taken a lot for me to accept that my actions, my words, my apathy and my choice of symbols have consequences beyond my intention.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_28.name: 842c
Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_28.text: People have had to have patience with me.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_29.text: It is my intention for my daughters to grow up speaking Southern English just as naturally as me. But it is also my intention to improve their heritage, to raise them to love all people not in word alone but in deed and action.

Paragraph:ef3324a2dec7_30.text: They will still be Southern even if the only place they see a Confederate flag is in a history book.

$Post:f2fa09b00f76.previewContent.subtitle: How one conversation changed my mind.
